understanding.title: Understanding Tuberculosis
understanding.subtitle: An infectious disease that requires attention
understanding.what_is_content:
Tuberculosis is a disease caused by a bacterium called Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which, after a latent phase, becomes active. This active form of the disease corresponds to a multiplication of the bacterium. It is accompanied by symptoms and requires prolonged treatment with specific antibiotics.

It most often affects the lungs, in which case it is called pulmonary tuberculosis. The disease is contagious only when the lungs are affected. It can also affect other parts of the body, such as lymph nodes, kidneys, brain, bones, etc. In these cases, the disease is not contagious. It can sometimes affect several organs.

But this disease can be avoided, and it can be cured if treated correctly.
understanding.transmission_content:
Tuberculosis is transmitted through the air by a person whose lungs are affected when they cough, sneeze, or talk. Transmission requires prolonged and close contact with a person who has contagious pulmonary tuberculosis, for example when living in the same household as the contagious person or traveling together in a vehicle.

When tuberculosis affects parts of the body other than the lungs, it is not contagious.

Not all people in contact with a case of tuberculosis will necessarily be infected, let alone become ill.

Pulmonary tuberculosis is less contagious than diseases like the flu or measles.
understanding.how_occurs_content:
Tuberculosis occurs when the tuberculosis bacteria 'wake up' in the body.

Indeed, when a person breathes in the bacteria, they remain dormant in the body, without causing disease. They remain in a state of rest, inactive, dormant. This is called latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). The infected person, carrier of a latent tuberculosis infection, is not sick. They show no symptoms and are not contagious.

The bacteria can remain in the body for the entire life of the infected person without doing anything, as their immune system can contain the infection.

But for 1 in 10 infected people, the bacteria 'wake up' after the latent phase and become active by multiplying. The person then becomes ill.

The awakening most often occurs within two years of transmission or when there is immunosuppression related to a disease (such as AIDS), certain immunosuppressive drugs, a state of malnutrition, or age (the elderly and very young children have a weak immune system).

In the absence of any clinical and radiological signs, the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis infection can be made using immunological tests such as the tuberculin skin test (TST) or interferon-gamma release assays (IGRA).

symptoms.title: Symptoms and Treatment
symptoms.what_are_symptoms: What are the symptoms of tuberculosis?
symptoms.what_are_symptoms_content:
Symptoms vary depending on which part of the body is affected. But in all cases, the disease can cause the following signs: fever, intense night sweats, great fatigue, and loss of appetite and weight.

In the case of pulmonary tuberculosis, there is a cough.

The persistence of these signs for several weeks should suggest tuberculosis and should prompt a visit to the doctor.
symptoms.how_to_treat_content:
In France, tuberculosis is very treatable today. Treatment requires taking several drugs every day for at least six months. They must be taken on an empty stomach. In practice, they should be taken once a day, all at once, at least half an hour before eating. You can also wait 2 hours after a meal to take them.

Treatment is accompanied by regular monitoring such as blood tests.

At the start of treatment, started in the hospital, the person with contagious pulmonary tuberculosis is isolated (single room, mask, etc.) to avoid infecting others.

It is very important not to stop treatment, otherwise the disease may return, and to avoid the development of drug resistance, which would then be ineffective.

Social security covers 100% of the treatment.

prevention.title: Prevention
prevention.how_to_prevent_content:
Prevention involves early and targeted BCG vaccination for at-risk children, as well as screening provided by Tuberculosis Control Centers (CLAT), both around cases of contagious tuberculosis and in the most exposed populations.

Although BCG vaccination is no longer mandatory in France since 2007, it remains strongly recommended, especially for children under five years of age with risk factors related to their environment or close contacts (particularly a family history of tuberculosis or links with a country where tuberculosis is very common).

Vaccination is recommended from the age of 1 month, preferably during the 2nd month. It protects against severe forms of tuberculosis, particularly tuberculous meningitis.

CLATs play a central role in the prevention of tuberculosis. When a case of contagious tuberculosis is diagnosed, the CLAT, informed by the health authorities, conducts an investigation to find people who have been in close contact with the patient. These people can then benefit from screening, including a medical consultation, chest X-ray, and immunological test (such as the tuberculin test or IGRA).

In the event of detection of latent tuberculosis infection, the CLAT offers preventive treatment to prevent it from progressing to active tuberculosis.

In addition, the CLAT also organizes targeted screening in certain more exposed populations, such as people from countries where tuberculosis is common, in order to detect the disease as early as possible.

q1.question: What causes tuberculosis?
q1.explanation: Tuberculosis is caused by a bacterium called Mycobacterium tuberculosis, also known as Koch's bacillus.

q2.question: How is tuberculosis transmitted?
q2.explanation: Tuberculosis is transmitted through the air when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks, releasing droplets containing the bacterium.

q3.question: Which form of tuberculosis is contagious?
q3.explanation: Only pulmonary tuberculosis is contagious because it affects the lungs and allows airborne transmission.

q4.question: How long does tuberculosis treatment usually last?
q4.explanation: Tuberculosis treatment usually lasts 6 months, sometimes more depending on the case. It is crucial to follow it completely.

q5.question: What does LTBI mean?
q5.explanation: LTBI stands for Latent Tuberculosis Infection. This is when the bacterium is present but 'dormant', without symptoms or contagion.

q6.question: When should tuberculosis medications be taken?
q6.explanation: Tuberculosis medications should be taken on an empty stomach, at least 30 minutes before meals or 2 hours after.

q7.question: What is the main symptom of pulmonary tuberculosis?
q7.explanation: The main symptom of pulmonary tuberculosis is a persistent cough lasting more than 3 weeks.

q8.question: What happens if treatment is stopped too early?
q8.explanation: Stopping treatment too early can lead to a relapse of the disease and the development of drug resistance.
